Name: Mary Poppins Returns
Review: Could have been a great movie if it weren't a Mary Poppins sequel.

Name: The Ballad of Buster Scruggs
Review: Western vignettes that oscillate between acceptable and outstanding.

Name: Mirai
Review: Second act is too long, with a winding and predictable troupe of having each family member shown in fantasy flashback. If it had a better second act it could contend as a masterpiece.

Name: Mary Queen of Scots
Review: Continues the troupe of white people putting POC in their historical dramas without mentioning race. Could have worked better as a fiction piece. 8/10 costume and set dec.

Name: Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse
Review: The strange choice to blur objects in forefront for aesthetic reasons knocks down an otherwise flawless visual experience with a weak story.

Name: De Palma
Review: I could listen to this man read the phone book.

Name: The Favourite
Review: Some very strange montage scenes derail an otherwise masterclass in pacing for non-action oriented films.

Name: Aquaman
Review: Was cool when he rode sea Godzilla I guess.

Name: Dirty Harry
Review: "I don't remember how many bullets I've fired." Weird flex, but okay.

Name: Smallfoot
Review: Turns out James Gordon is less unlikable when I can't see his face and he's just reading lines written for him......but just barely.

Name: Roma
Review:
This film has it all! An incredibly boring plot, pacing a slug could outrun, and shot in black and white to seem 'important'. If this was a silent film shot on film it would have won every Oscar. 

If I could give it 0 stars I would. I've seen a series of 5 pictures convey a more interesting story.

Name: Brothers
Review: Two of what I would have considered the most overrated actors before seeing this film come together for one of the greatest performances in modern war cinema.

Name: Replicas
Review: HOLY SHIT THIS WAS BAD.

Name: On the Basis of Sex
Review: It's like the liberal version of those "god's not dead" movies but with better acting and set design.

Name: A Star Is Born
Review: The only real 5/5 this year; it has all my favorite things about movies and alcoholism in it.

Name: Bumblebee
Review: Underwhelming girl and her horse story.

Name: Alita: Battle Angel
Review: Better than expected. RR will never make another masterpiece, but that doesn't mean his movies can't be enjoyed.

Name: Can You Ever Forgive Me?
Review: I watch a movie like this and while I can't justify a perfect 5/5, I can't really articulate how it could have possibly been any better.

Name: Minding the Gap
Review: The pacing issues in the middle are more than compensated for by the punch to the gut ending.

Name: The Screen Director
Review: Interesting snapshot into how filmmakers perceive themselves.

Name: Feathered Cocaine
Review: Subject matter is much more interesting than I originally thought, but the execution was lacking.

Name: Final Offer
Review: Honestly never been much of a fan of organized labor unions, but goddamn if this doc didn't make me want to move to Toronto and work on a factory line.

Name: Jezebel
Review:
"I like my convictions undiluted -- same as I like my bourbon"

\\

Hard not to give a REAL hard cringe during any sequence involving the slaves. Particularly jarring is the sequence where Bette Midler leads the chorus of slaves in 'raising a ruckus'. Still a great film.

Name: Tickled
Review: At least being chubby and unattractive keeps me from having weirdos try and recruit me into underground tickling rings.

Name: The Tickle King
Review: Majority of the shoot is just an extended confrontation of the antagonist showing up at a Q&A. Very interesting, but raises more questions than get answered.

Name: Inside the Goldmine
Review:
This video vomit experience is so completely insulting I don't have the capacity to describe it. 

Do not let the cover fool you; Drew Barrymore is not in this movie. 

I am going to assume (for both the sake of the filmmaker and myself) that all of the dialogue is improve. If that is NOT the case, it would mean that everything was shot in a single take where the actors were constantly forgetting their lines and screaming "FUCK" as loudly as they could to replace the written dialogue. 

This torture session is a crime against cinema. 

It should be punishable under the Geneva Convention. 

How do I give negative stars?

Name: You Were Never Really Here
Review:
"You just hate women directors"

This was so close to being a masterpiece. Shot for shot it's just so cleanly executed. Until the end. That stupid fucking ending that's telegraphed from a million miles away because every female director feels the need to 'subvert the genre' by having the FRAGILE YOUNG GIRL become the REAL HERO who DON'T NEED NO MAN. 

It's not subversion to do what everyone expects. It's not unique or interesting to portray a woman in a state of vulnerability and then have her be the one who saves herself at the end. It's the same story that everyone is writing now. 

If she had just told the story of the girl, I think that would have been compelling. Or if she had actually followed through with the Joe character and gave him something of an ending. But instead we get the same trite story being told with a different wrapper. 

I get it. Women can be strong too and they don't need a man to save them. We all get it. Now can we go back to telling a story? One that doesn't have to rely on an 'edgy' narrative hook?

Name: Shoplifters
Review: This film touches on everything it is to be human.

Name: Cold War
Review:
Honestly a let down. 

Editing was shockingly good. 

Music was excellent. 

Story dragged.

Name: Rabbit à la Berlin
Review: Really cute doc on how rabbits lived before, during, and after the Berlin Wall construction.

Name: How to Train Your Dragon: The Hidden World
Review: Some pretty visuals

Name: High Flying Bird
Review: A corny imitation of what this movie could have been with a black filmmaker. Instead we got a middle aged white dude wishing to reclaim his sense of youth by larping with an iphone trying to make a black statement piece.

Name: Fighting with My Family
Review: Well I cried during a wrestling movie, so that's where I'm at with life currently.

Name: Captain Marvel
Review: Captain "Meh" Val

Name: Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father
Review:
"I've never seen a coffin so small before. They shouldn't have them that size."

This one hurts too much.

Name: Sabrina
Review:
"I should have believed you: there's a front seat and a back seat and a window in between"

Christ it's Bogart, Hepburn and directed by Wilder.

Name: A Star Is Born
Review: Judy Garland.

Name: Iliza Shlesinger: War Paint
Review:
The bit with her dog should have been funny? 

The P90X segment was nice until it became a very long bit about male prison rape 🙄. 

The long segment about becoming a pharmacist also should have been funny? I really don't understand why none of this is landing for me. It seems to be well written? And she's clearly really energetic and brings a lot of physicality to her work. Specifically for this bit, I even enjoy the topic. 

But this is one of the more boring specials I've seen. 

I think there's a point where having a bunch of energy comes off as desperately wanting the audience to enjoy your very mediocre content. 

"I don't care what the Brits eat, we won the war." Just......what is my response to be to this? 

Wow, she just said the N word. 

"I think they fucking do use nutmeg and that's why it burns so much" This was the punchline to a 5 minute(maybe? Maybe longer? I'm starting to lose sight of time) bit about how a particular KY jelly burns. 

There's a pattern where her jokes all tend to speed up as they go on. It's like she's trying to outrun her own jokes. 

I think the problem is that nothing she says is unique or surprising in any way. I know where every bit is going when it begins.

Name: Russell Peters: Notorious
Review:
His material can be difficult to digest due to it all being race based observational humor, but he does a better job navigating it than most comedians. 

It’s just not material I particularly enjoy. 2 1/2 stars for being able to pull off sensitive material.

Name: Aziz Ansari: Buried Alive
Review:
Solid 6/10.  

I hate not giving a little higher of a rating since the highs on this one are fantastic. 

The middle portion had some really fantastic crowd work as well as some very tightly constructed and well delivered bits. 

However this loses two stars due to the more performative moments towards the end of the special during the third act. Specifically the songs in the club parts were awkward to sit through. Just a little too over the top for my tastes.

Name: Jim Jefferies: Bare
Review:
A solid 2/5 

The more performative bits were a drag, just because it’s all clearly imagined. 

Some of the bits were recycled but you can’t blame an alcoholic for memory loss. 

Clearly thinks of himself as a philosopher among the last call groupies.

Name: Chelsea Handler: Uganda Be Kidding Me Live
Review:
There was a very long bit about trying to determine the color of her own asshole. 

Do with that what you will.

Name: Chelsea Peretti: One of the Greats
Review: “Yeaaaah all my Buffy heads” Uproarious Laughter Idk, if you’re going to use a laugh track at least don’t make it so noticeable.

Name: Bill Burr: I'm Sorry You Feel That Way
Review: Engaging throughout but only found myself laughing once or twice throughout the entire special.

Name: Iliza Shlesinger: Freezing Hot
Review:
“uS WoMEn ArE liKE ThIS” 

At least she slowed down the delivery from the last special.

Name: Ralphie May: Unruly
Review: He had an extended segment where he argued for gay marriage legalization in Florida......because Florida........looks like a penis.

Name: Aziz Ansari: Live at Madison Square Garden
Review: He relies VERY heavily on “wow dating amirite” but he does it better than anyone else.

Name: Chris D'Elia: Incorrigible
Review:
I fell asleep halfway through it but I’m going to count it anyway. 

Otherwise I would end up killing mused 3/4 of the way through and wouldn’t be able to finish this list. 

He has some moments. 

I don’t know. 

I’m starting to hate myself.

Name: Jen Kirkman: I'm Gonna Die Alone (And I Feel Fine)
Review:
After the longest run of absolute trash stand up comedy specials I have ever watched thanks to the geniuses that signed Netflix’s first 15 or so comedy special deals, we finally hit a jackpot. 

Had never heard of her but the entire special was great. 

After watching the second special with the comedian who makes the goat noises (not a sardonic turn of phrase to try and insult her, that’s a genuine description of her show) I seriously considered the option that I may never experience joy in my life. 

Jen may not have saved my life (debatable) but she absolutely saved my sense of humor.

Name: Chris Tucker Live
Review:
The second Netflix special with large portions dedicated to a rich person talking about their trip to Africa. 

This one was better than the Chelsea Handler one I guess. 

Chris Tucker was about twice as funny as I thought he would be going into this.
